=== RS485 ===

lspci returns '''ATI Technologies Inc RS485 [Radeon Xpress 1100 IGP]'''. Splash screen <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/136582|bug #136582]]</nowiki> affects release 7.10 but not 8.04.

== Ubuntu 8.10 and later ==
Since Ubuntu 8.10 3D and desktop effects works out of the box with the open source -ati driver.

== Ubuntu 8.04 and previous ==
The user can choose between two drivers: The open source -ati driver and the closed-source fglrx driver. Enabling 3D acceleration requires extra user configuration anyway.
=== Enable DRI -ati ===
Direct rendering has been turned off by default for RS48x/RS690 since revision 6.7.194 of <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/RadeonDriver|xserver-xorg-video-ati]]</nowiki> due to missing features and unresolved bugs in the mesa library. The situation has changed with the release of Ubuntu 8.10, where DRI is supported out of the box. Ubuntu 8.04 users can update to a backported mesa package from Andrius Å tikonas PPA and enable DRI in the driver shipped with Ubuntu 8.04.

1. Add these software sources and update your mesa packages.
<pre>
deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/stikonas/ubuntu hardy main
deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/stikonas/ubuntu hardy main
</pre>
2. Add these options to respective sections in xorg.conf
<pre>
Section "Device"
	Identifier	"Configured Video Device"
	Option 		"DRI" "true"
	Option     	"GARTSize" "64"
EndSection

Section "DRI"
        Mode 0666
EndSection
        
Section "Extensions"
        Option "Composite" "Enable"
EndSection
</pre>
3. Restart the X server by logging out and back in, or typing <code>sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart</code>.

4. Check status flag

<pre>
$ glxinfo | grep "direct rendering"
</pre>

5. Check functionality by invoking glxgears.

<pre>
$ glxgears
</pre>

=== Enable DRI -fglrx ===
The proprietary binary driver produced by AMD/ATI is commonly known as <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BinaryDriverHowto/ATI|fglrx]]</nowiki>. It can easily be installed using ''System->Administration>Hardware Drivers''.

2. Restart xserver by logging out and back in, or typing <code>sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart</code>.

3. Check status flag

<pre>
$ glxinfo | grep "direct rendering"
</pre>

4. Check functionality by invoking glxgears.

<pre>
$ glxgears
</pre>

5.Change overlay type to Xvideo if video upscaling looks blocky.
<code>$ sudo aticonfig --ovt=Xv</code>

=== Desktop Effects ===
Desktop effects don't work by default up to Ubuntu 8.04. To make them work the user has to enable the Direct Rendering Interface and AIGLX with the open source driver as described above. The second alternative is to install the proprietary driver <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BinaryDriverHowto/ATI|fglrx]]</nowiki>.

1. Enable Direct Rendering Interface or install fglrx

2. Enable AIGLX by adding options to xorg.conf
<pre>
Section "Device"
	Option          "XAANoOffscreenPixmaps"
EndSection

Section "ServerLayout"
	Option          "AIGLX"	"true"
EndSection

Section "ServerFlags"
	Option "AIGLX" "on"
EndSection
</pre>

3. Add this line to '''.config/compiz/compiz-manager'''
<pre>
SKIP_CHECKS="yes"
</pre>

4. Restart xserver by logging out and back in, or typing <code>sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart</code>.

5. Finally turn on desktop effects in menu Preferences>Appearance>Visual effects.

== External monitor ==
External output works with open driver. Use <code>xrandr</code> to configure. Display device hot plugging work, outputs must be configured manually. See <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/RadeonDriver#head-90dff5c614b4caa08128ef9a736dd430d0be8e3c|driver documentation]]</nowiki> for more information
